CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1. Voyager 2\'s Interface. The top panel (A) provides bookmark gallery and undo commands. The data panel (B) contains the dataset name, data fields (C), and wildcard fields (D). Wildcard fields let users create multiple views in parallel by serving as "variables" over an enumerated set of fields. Categorical, temporal, and quantitative field wildcards are provided by default, though users can manually author cartoon videos containing desired fields (E). The encoding panel (F) contains shelves for mapping fields to visual channels via drag-and-drop, and a control for selecting mark type. A _wildcard shelf_ (G) lets users add fields without selecting a specific channel, allowing the system to suggest appropriate encodings. The _filter_ panel (H) shows dynamic query controls for filtering. The primary focus view (I) displays the currently specified chart. _Related views_ (J) show recommended plots relevant to the focus view. Related summaries (K) suggest aggregate plots to summarize the data. _Field suggestions_ (L) show the results of encoding one additional field within the focus view.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG10.png: 'Figure 10. Mean subject ratings and 95% CIs of relative tool values for question answering and open-ended exploration (symmetric 7-point scale) from our study and [39]. Voyager 2 has higher overall ratings than Voyager and PoleStar in terms of supporting both analysis phases.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG11.png: 'Figure 11. Mean usefulness ratings and 95% CIs for Voyager 2 features on a symmetric 5-point scale (<2 not useful, +2 very useful) show that subjects find both _related views_ and _whlceards_ features useful. Labels include the number of subjects who used and rated each feature.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2. Upon loading a dataset, the focus view (\\(\\blacktriangle\\)) is empty. The relation views show univariate summaries (B) for all fields.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3. Dropping two quantitative field wildcards onto the wildcard shelves. Voyager 2 automatically chooses encodings, producing scatterplots that show bivariate relationships between all quantitative fields.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Figure 4. Setting the focus view to the colored scatterplot of _hors exposure_, miles per gallon, and origin in Figure 1-L. The related views panel then displays _samuaries_ (A) and _alternative_ encodings (B) of the focus view.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG5.png: 'Figure 5: Mapping a quantitative field wildcard to \\(x\\) and origin to \\(y\\) (A) produces a gallery of plots. A _wildcard function_ enumerates no function (none) and mean (B-C), generating strip plots of raw values and bar charts of mean values (D). The \\(\\hat{\\gamma}\\) in (A) denotes the wildcard function.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG6.png: 'Figure 6. _Wideard shelf_ (A) allows users to consider alternative ways to encode _origin_ (by using color or by faceting).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG7.png: 'Figure 7. CampassQL queries: focus view and wildcard specification.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG8.png: 'Figure 8: CompassQL queries for different categories of related views.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG9.png: 'Figure 9: Mean counts and 95% CIs of unique field sets shown and interacted with. Users view and interact with more fields using Yoyager 2.\n\n'
